<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XV
PROMULGATION OF THE FAITH OF
ZARATHUSHTRA
The Avestan people. The races that formed the
Zoroastrian fold were the Bactrians, the Medes, and
the Persians, who successively rose to political
independence in Ancient Iran. The Bactrians of the
Northeast, the Medians of the Northwest, and the
Persians of the Southwest, were politically welded
into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> Persian nation, under the Achaemenian
empire. This process of blending these <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span>
peoples into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> homogeneous nation under the
creed of Zoroaster was completed by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of the
of Persia by Alexander the Great.
Zoroastrianism takes its root in Eastern Iran. The
Later Avestan texts speak of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Vishtaspa as the
very arm and pillar of Zoroastrianism, the defender of
the Faith, who gave an impetus to the religion, which
until then had experienced only an extremely
chequered career, and who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> the faith <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> and
renowned throughout the world.1 With all the zeal 1. Yt13.99, 100.
and <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> characteristic of converts Zarathushtra's
followers worked actively for the promulgation of the 2. Y8.7.
faith. The authors of the Younger Avestan period
depict Zarathushtra as <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t9 t11 t12 t15 t16 t17 t22 t24 t27 hoverable">saying</span> that he will exhort the 3. Yt16.17.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> and clan, town and country to
embrace the Mazdayasnian religion and teach them
to practise it faithfully in their thoughts, their words,
and their deeds.2 The zealous priests invoke Chisti,
the heavenly associate of Daena, or religion, to grant
them a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> memory and strength for their body.

The Medes and Persians of Western Iran. We have
already seen that the Aryan race had established their
settlements in Northwestern Iran from about 2000
B.C. and that the Kassites and Mitannis had ruled
over considerable tradts between 1700 B.C. and 1400
B.C., The other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> peoples of the same race that
successively rose to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> during the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span>
millennium before the Christian era were the Medes
and the Persians. So close was their racial affinity that
the Biblical and classical writers generally use their
names as alternative terms. The Medes or Mada are
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> mentioned by their names in the Assyrian
inscriptions in the ninth century B.C. They
overthrew the Assyrian empire in about 708 B.C.,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> replacing the Semitic domination in Western
Iran by the Aryan.
The earliest mention of the Persians is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> in the
Assyrian inscriptions where it is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> that the Assyrian

King Shalmaneser II led a campaign against the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of Parsua in the Zagros in the ninth century
B.C. These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> were probably identical with the
Persians who rose to <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> later in the further east.
They lived in Pars, <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> in its Greek <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> as Persis,
and were a tributary subject <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> under the Medes.
Their ruling <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> was <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">name</span> of
Hakhamanish, the head of the royal house, <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> in
history in its Greek form, Achaemenes. Cyrus
wrested the royal sceptre from the Medes and
founded the Persian empire in about 558 B.C.
Not <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Vishtaspa, the royal
patron of Zarathushtra, the Kingly Glory left the
eastern line of the Iranian kings and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> flew to the
west. With the shifting of the political sphere of
influence, the centre of religious authority [131]
gravitated towards the west. Ragha, hereafter,
became the pontifical seat of the descendants of the
prophet. The temporal and <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> here was 9. Y19.18.
vested in the chief pontiff of the Zoroastrian world.9
Religious influence radiated from this ecclesiastical
centre, and the Magian neighbours, who formed the
priestly caste <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the Medo-Persians, were
probably the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> to imbibe the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> Ideas and
gradually to spread them <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the peoples Western
Iran.
The Achaemenian empire was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> up of various
nationalities of diverse faiths, and the rulers were
always tolerant towards the religions of these subject
races. Guided by political expediency, they often
built or restored the temples of alien peoples, and
occasionally <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> honoured the Jewish, Egyptian,
Babylonian, and Greek divinities.10 Cyrus ordered the
restoration of temple at Jerusalem,11 and Darius, the

Righteousness as the only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> path,31 or the truest
path,32 and Darius exhorts in the same vein not to
leave pathim tyâm râstâm, 'The Path of Truth,' not to
slight the commandments of Auramazda and not to
sin.33-34 Closely parallel to Y37.1, which enumerates
Ahura Mazda's earthly creation, and which formula is
recited by devout Zoroastrians as grace before meals,
the <span class="t25 hoverable">Old</span> Persian Inscriptions state that Auramazda has
created this earth, yonder heaven, man, and peace for
man.35

The Later Avesta names the demon of drought
Duzhyairya.40 and Darius invokes Auramazda and his
associates to protect his country from Dushiyar.41
The inscriptions do not mention Angra Mainyu. We
have, however, seen that Darius uses Drauga, Lie,
with the emphasis that the Later Avesta puts on
Angra Mainyu, and in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> seeing all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> in Drauga
instead of in Angra Mainyu, Darius is more faithful to
the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of the Gathas than the Later Avesta is. It is
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> that the inscriptions <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> mention Zarathushtra
by name, but they undoubtedly breathe the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
his teachings. The royal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of the Achaemenians
is a devout Mazda-worshipper at its rise, it imbibes
the Zoroastrian cult gradually and is fully
Mazdayasnian Zarathushtrian by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of its
downfall.
Magi, the Zoroastrian priesthood of Western Iran.
Herodotus tells us that the Magi formed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the
six tribes into which the Medes were divided and
constituted their sacerdotal class.42 They wore the
white robe and covered the head with the woolen
tiara with <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> flaps on each side to, cover the
mouth.43 The Median empire was short-lived. Cyrus
overthrew Astyages, the last Median king, in 550
B.C. and laid the foundation of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
Achaemenian empire. The Persians <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> conquered
the earthly possessions of the Medes and the Magi,
their priests; but they were in turn conquered by the

their position. The classical writers held their names

the East. Magic and magician are the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">words</span>

the sacred fire, kept it burning on the battlefield, and
invoked <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> help for the victory of the king.
Herodotus tells us that the <span class="t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t15 t19 t20 t23 t25 hoverable">holy</span> chariot drawn by
eight white horses followed the armies of Xerxes.
The Magi <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> sacrificial offerings at various stages

Persian arms, in which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> and the Persian
soldiers in the army participated.47 They were held in
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> esteem, and their exalted position at the court
of the kings ensured them a considerable influence

over the people. They were looked <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> as the wise

the ceremonies, chanted the hymns, sacrificed at the
altar, explained omens, practised divination,
expounded dreams, and ministered to the various
religious wants of the people.48
It seems that the Magi <span class="t4 hoverable">took</span> a <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to supplant
the religious practices of the Persians by their own.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> races differed very widely on some of the

be kept pure from defilement. Hence they exposed
the corpses of the dead to be devoured by birds;

The earliest Greek writer to acquaint the Western
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> with the history of the nations of Ancient Iran
is Herodotus, who wrote about a century and a
quarter before the fall of the Achaemenian empire.
Writing at a period when the Persians were in the
zenith of their <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> in Western Iran, and when the
Magi were the recognized class, he, with the other
writers that followed him, acquainted the West with
the Magi. The athravans, the real custodians of the
Avesta and the guardians of the Zoroastrian symbol of
fire, are unknown to these writers. This <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be due

to the fact that Eastern Iran, which was the home of
the athravans, had politically declined, and the
writers are mainly concerned with the Persians of the
west, and their immediate predecessors, the Medes.
The Avestan texts do not recognize the Magi. The
forms derived from the term maga, 'great' occurring in
the Gathas and the Later Avesta do not represent this
priestly class. We find a solitary passage, presumably
a late interpolation, which pronounces a curse <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
those who ill-treat the Magi.51 We <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> add a passage
in which Ahura Mazda tells Zarathushtra that he
prefers a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who has a wife to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> who lives as a
magus, that is, lives in continence.52 The class
designation of the priests in the Avestan <span class="t2 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t20 t24 t29 hoverable">text</span> is
persistently athravan. The disposal of the dead by the
exposure to the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the sun, the reverence for the
elements, fire, water, and earth, the stringent laws for
51. Y65.7.
bodily cleanliness, the active crusade against noxious
creatures, are some of the salient features of the
52. Vd4.47.
religious practices and beliefs of the Magi that we
glean from the writings of the Greek authors. These
<span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> the cardinal tenets of the Vendidad and are all
associated with the athravans, who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> up the
official priesthood of the Avestan people. It is not a
Magus who cleanses the defiled by ablution
ceremonials, heals the sick by [137] the recital of the
<span class="t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t15 t19 t20 t23 t25 hoverable">holy</span> spells, and moves about with a penom over his
mouth, and a khrafstraghna in his hand; but it is an
athravan who exercises all these powers and more.
The sacerdotal class is <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> by the title of athravan
throughout the texts. It is the only privileged priestly
class that the Avesta recognizes.

<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XVI
ZARATHUSHTRA IN THE YOUNGER AVESTA
Zarathushtra is the chief of mankind as Tishtrya is
of the stars. On the banks of the river Darej lived
Pourushaspa of the family of the Spitamas in a small
house.1 A boy babe was born <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> him. In
consultation with the elders of the clan, the child was
named Zarathushtra. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> donned a festive garb,
the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> shone with a brighter glory, trees strewed
flowers, on the ground roses bloomed in luxuriant
profusion, flowers and leaves and grass scented the
air with sweet fragrance, creepers climbed the hedges
in riotous luxuriance, the birds carolled in the air,
myriads of tiny drops of the morning dew shone <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span>

<span class="t7 t10 t15 t25 hoverable">end</span> of time, up to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> that the victorious
Saviour came, Zarathushtra tells Angra Mainyu that
he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> smite his evil.32 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> was he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> in the
material <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> to proclaim the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">word</span> for the

headlong, weeping and wailing, at his sight and their

Vairya and drove back the demons beneath the

beneath the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> the daevas that were stalking the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> in the shape of <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> beings.36 He was the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span>

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> now warmly welcomed him and heard him
with bated breath. His countenance radiated <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span>

awakened to <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> life. The faithful undertake to tread

triumphed in lighting a beacon to illumine the path
for mankind to tread.

[145]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XVII
THE YOUNGER AVESTAN RELIGION
From the Gathas to the Later Avesta, a retrograde
step. We now enter <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> field of
investigation, and move in an entirely changed
atmosphere as we proceed. The buoyant <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of the
Gathic hymns is preserved to a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> extent in the
composition of the Haptanghaiti, or the section to
'Seven Chapters' in the Avestan Yasna, <span class="t23 hoverable">written</span> in the
Gathic dialect during the transition period that
intervened between the close of the Gathic age and
the opening of the Avestan period. The lofty tone of
the earlier compositions gradually declines, and the
greater <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the Yasna, Yashts, and Vendidad

becomes heavy and monotonous. On only rare
occasions do the texts exhibit sudden flashes of
transcendent beauty and devout fervour. The
growing tendency is for complexity and
concreteness. The Gathas generally dealt with the
abstract concepts. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Every</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the Amesha Spentas,
as we have already seen, impersonated some cardinal
virtue. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> Asha, the genius of righteousness, and
Haurvatat, that of perfection, have each a Yasht
consecrated to them in the Younger Avesta, the
abstract virtues of these archangels do not receive
any recognition in these hymns. The secondary and
concrete qualities with <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> associations loom larger
in the thoughts of their composers than do the
primary qualifications. Rather than dealing with the
righteousness of Asha Vahishta and the perfection of
Haurvatat, the later texts expatiate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> their healing
powers by <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> of the recital of the various
formulas of magical efficacy and the spells to drive
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span> the demons of diseases and death. This general
tendency of drifting towards the concrete and
material in religion is the characteristic feature of the
times and endures throughout the Younger Avestan
as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as the subsequent Pahlavi period, in which it
reaches its climax.
Daena, Chisti, Mithra, Raman, Rata, Manthra,
Airyaman, Asha, Hvare, Maunghah, Asman, Ushah,
Atar, and Zam furnish [146] us with instances in
which terms that were <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> in the Gathas to connote
the ordinary meanings are now personified as angels.
The angels that outshine the archangels. Some of
the Yazatas, both those or pure Iranian extraction
and those of Indo-Iranian origin, have risen to such a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> popularity during this period that they are

honoured more than the Amesha Spentas. The angels
Anahita and Tishtrya, Mithra, and Verethraghna
figure more prominently than the archangels Vohu
Manah and Asha Vahishta, Armaiti, and Ameretat.
Some of the longest Yashts, or sacrificial hymns, are
composed in their honour. The Yasht dedicated to
Mithra, for example, is eight times larger than the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> composed in honour of Ahura Mazda himself.
The archangels, who are higher in the <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span>
hierarchy, who occupied a unique position in the
Gathas, and <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> glory the prophet <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> sang with
his clarion voice to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of Iran, have now
either to content themselves with short laudatory
compositions or go entirely <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any special
dedication. Some of the attributes that are the
prerogative of Ahura Mazda alone are lavishly
applied to the leading angels; but the authors are
sparing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> to parsimony when they confer
honorific epithets on the Amesha Spentas.
Their imprecations <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> their careless votaries. A
few of the Yazatas, or Adorable Ones, are conjointly
honoured with Ahura Mazda in the same strain. They
are eager to help <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> and stand by his side in the
hour of his need, if they are invoked. They help man,
if <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> remembers them. Moreover, they are
themselves strengthened in their <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> by man's
offerings. Tishtrya despondently complains to Ahura
Mazda that he is worsted by his adversary Apaosha
because mankind do not propitiate him with
sacrifices as they ought to. If they did so, Tishtrya
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be emboldened and enabled to conduct his
warfare with the demon of drought more vigorously.
Tishtrya complains that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> do not <span class="t27 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span>
him to the extent that they do <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> the other angels,
who are more popular <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> them. Mithra, likewise,

complains of man's occasional neglect of his
invocation, which evokes his displeasure. And Mithra
is terrible when angered. Unless <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> appeases his
wrath by abundant sacrifices, he punishes his
wretched victim mercilessly. Similarly, the Fravashis,
or Guardian Spirits, are the most helpful genii, but on
[147] condition that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> propitiates them with
sacrifices. When satisfied, they are of indescribable
help, but once offended they are hard to deal with.
They are to be approached with religious awe. They
are to be feared, rather than loved. This fear of the
celestial beings <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> engender obedience in man, but
not devotion. And devotion is the higher of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
virtues.

Zarathushtra's monologues in the Gathas as against
his dialogues in the Avesta. In the Gathas the
prophet addressed several questions to Ahura Mazda,
but the replies were left to be inferred from the
context. An advance is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> this method, and
now we have Zoroaster depicted as putting questions, 13. Vd2.21, 22.
and Ahura Mazda himself as answering them
categorically. To invest their compositions with
<span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> sanction and prophetic authority, the later
sages wrote in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a dialogue between Ahura
Mazda and his prophet. The greater <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the

Vendidad and some of the Yashts are composed in
this style. Escorted by the celestial Yazatas, Ahura
Mazda comes down to Airyana Vaejah to attend a
meeting of mortals convened by Yima, and warns
him of the coming destructive winter and frost.13
The Avesta looks with unrelenting abhorrence <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
idols and images of divinities. Idolatry in any <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> is
sin. The Shah Namah abounds in passages depicting
the Persian kings and heroes as conducting a crusade
against idols and idol-worship. The conquering
armies of Persia always destroyed the idols and razed 14. 1.131.
their temples to the ground. Herodotus writes that
15. Diogenes Laertius,
the Persians did not erect idols.14 Sotion adds that
they hated idols.15The statues of <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> divinities Prooem. 6.
were, however, not unknown <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the
Achaemenians. The winged figure floating over the 16. Cited by Clemens
head of Darius on the rock sculptures at Behistan is Alexandrinus,
probably a representation of Auramazda. We have it Protreptica, 5, 65, 3.
on the authority of Berosus that the Achaemenian
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> Artaxerxes Mnemon (B.C. 404-358) had statues 17. P. 733.

We find no traces of such open disregard of the
genuine teachings of the faith, when the priesthood
firmly established its influence. Orthodox
Zoroastrianism <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> sanctioned any <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of idolworship in Iran.
The Yazatas, or angels, Tishtrya, Verethraghna,
Dahma Afriti, and Damoish Upamana introduce a
novel feature in the theology of this period. They are

pictured as assuming various forms or man, horse, and
other objects in the performance of their allotted
work.

<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XVIII
THE IDEA OF <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">GOD</span> IN THE MILLENNIUM
Notes: Yahweh, the only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> of the Hebrews. We have already seen the
eclipse of the <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> and the rise of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> ones in India during the
millennium that opened with Zarathushtra and ended with the advent of
Jesue. The monotheistic idea greatly developed during this period <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the
Jews who were a subject race under the Persians and <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whose</span> religion was
influenced by Zoroastrianism. As Judaism later gave <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> to Christianity
and Mohammedanism, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of the belief in the godhead <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span>
this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> is of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> interest, and we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> discuss it in brief.
A race of sturdy nomads of Semitic stock tending their flocks from times
immemorial in the Arabian desert, of handsome features with prominent
aquiline nose, is seen settling down in Palestine about thirteen centuries
before the Christian era. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Many</span> of their kinsmen had laboured and suffered as
slaves in Egypt, until Moses <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> them deliverance. The Hebrews, as the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> are <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> to history, <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> their <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> settlement already populated
by the civilized Canaanites. The new-comers intermarried with them and
adopted their civilization. They succeeded later in founding a kingdom, and
under the heroic ruler David, Jerusalem became the centre of Jewish religious
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and the sanctuary of their national <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> Yahweh. During the period of
the divided kingdoms of Judah and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> prophetic literature of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> value
arose and enriched <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> thought. The kingdom of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> ended in 721
B.C., and Judah met with her destruction in 586 B.C. The Persians <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span>
the Jews deliverance and allowed them to restore the temple of Jerusalem
that was destroyed by Nebuchadnezzar. They flourished under the tolerant
Persian rule, codified their religious laws, collected and copied the sermons
and teachings and songs and ancient writings that they stilt possessed. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span>
in a few centuries more there [151] <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> into being the scriptures <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> as
the <span class="t25 hoverable">Old</span> Testament, the most precious legacy of the Hebrews to mankind.
When they had lived in small groups, each tribe had its God, whom the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> worshipped. Gradually a more powerful <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> these won

the universal respect of the race. He was Yahweh, worshipped in the earlier
stages in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a brazen serpent, until the idol worship gave <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> to a
purer <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of godhead. His dominion over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> was contested by Baal of
Tyre who received devotion from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> side by side with him both in
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> and Judah. Yahweh ultimately <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> out successful nnd remained the
only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> of the Hebrews. The prophet Amos (760 B.C.) raised him to
monotheistic grandeur and spoke as the mouth-piece of Yahweh. Hosea and
Isaiah preach against idolatry and the prophets are incessantly enjoining
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> not to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> idols or graven images and they exhort them
not to worship any other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> but Yahweh. It is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> that Yahweh is a jealous
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> and brooks no homage but to him. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">children</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> had suffered
in Egypt where they were in bondage. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> heard their groaning and had
compassion on them. He appeared <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> Moses in a flame of fire, burning in a
bush, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> that he had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> down to deliver the suffering <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">children</span> of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> from bondage to a <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> flowing with milk and honey. He gave him
ten commandments for the guidance of the people. Therein he demands that
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> fear him, walk in his ways, cleave <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> him, obey him, <span class="t7 hoverable">love</span> him,
and serve him with all his <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t19 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">heart</span> and all his soul. He has chosen <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span>
himself above all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> as a beacon of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and righteousness to mankind.
Consequently, he demands that they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> serve him faithfully, and
transgress not his commandments. If <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> walk in the Lord's statutes and
keep his commandments, he gives them seasonal rains, full crops, protection
against the attacks of animals and men, victory and offspring. He goes with
the armies of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Israel</span> to the battlefield and fights for them against the enemies.
But when they transgress his commandments, worship idols or other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> or
turn apostates, he breaks the pride of their power, lets loose their enemies
over them, and chastises them by visiting their country with plagues and
pestlences, famines and droughts, desolation and death. It was for the
inequities of his wayward <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">children</span> that Yahweh sent Tiglath-Pileser as his
scourge to punish them and <span class="t0 t2 t16 t18 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">put</span> them under [152] the Assyrian yoke. The
prophet Isaiah tells the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> that Yahweh uses Assyria as his rod to punish
them. Those who seek Yahweh, find him. He does not fail or forsake them.
But when they forsake him, and provoke him to anger, he casts them <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span>
forever. But <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> then if <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> repent, humble themselves before him, fall
down on their faces, rend their clothes, and weep, he relents, forgives them,
comes back to them, takes them under his protecting wings, helps them, and

prospers them. The Psalms and Prophets are replete with higher ethical
sentiment and aim at reforming the motives of conduct rather than
regulating it by ceremonial observances. They are full of fervent expressions
of religious emotion. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is depicted here as the compassionate <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t9 t10 t12 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t28 hoverable">Father</span> who
looks to all as his children. Judaism prepares the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> for a nobler type of
godhead that was to be preached by Jesus.
Taoism and Confucianism. Animism and ancestral worship ministered to the
<span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> needs of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in China from the earliest times. As in the other
parts of the world, the higher conceptions of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> or of some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> supreme
principle <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> were gradually evolving <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the sages.
Tradition places the Golden Age of China in about 3000 B.C. But the
authentic historical records do not go beyond a millennium before the
Christian era. It is in this period that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> religious and social ideals were
preached that have shaped the Chinese <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> for all time. The country was
harassed by feudal warfare, and famine and pestilence worked havoc, adding
to the misery of the people. Perplexed at the visitation of misfortunes and
calamities, wail goes up to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> from a poet in the eighth century B. C.
complaining that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> is unjust and merciless in its dealings with
mankind. Such complaints are <span class="t27 t28 hoverable">however</span> drowned in the chorus that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span>
does not will evil. It is man's own fault, in consequence of which he suffers.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> is born good, it is said, but when he goes astray from the path of
goodness, he brings calamity on his head. When there were strife and chaos
stalking the earth, the sages felt that peace and harmony reigned above in
heaven. Perfect was the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Way</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> or the Tao or the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> universal
principle, the ultimate reality. Happiness <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> fall to the lot of mankind, if
it followed faithfully the Way. The imitation of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Way</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> was
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> the ideal of earthly conduct. It was virtue and virtue <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> [153]
happiness. Man's duty was to cultivate the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Way</span> and the sages undertook to
teach it to mankind. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Way</span> was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> which to all thinkers looked alike,
but the methods of reaching it as taught by them were different.
Lao-tze, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> mystic born in 601 B.C., is the founder of Taoism. He
teaches quietism. Confucius (551-479 B.C.) is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and
teaches a moral code of personal conduct. His relgion is a discipline of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
and his system is a reaction against Taoism.

[154]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XIX
AHURA MAZDA
Ahura, Mazda, and Ahura Mazda. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">name</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> still retains its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
elements separate. These have not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> coalesced into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> word. In the
metrical sections of the Younger Avesta the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> elements are sometimes <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span>
apart from each other, or either <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of the terms <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> to designate
the Supreme Being, but in the prose compositions the collocation Ahura
Mazda generally occurs as a compound phrase. In the formation of
compounds, however, either Ahura or Mazda alone is <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> for the sake of
convenience. The Ahura compounds such as Ahura-dhâta, 'created by Ahura,'
Ahura-tkaesha, 'of the faith of Ahura,' or the adjectival <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> âhuiri, 'of Ahura,'
invariably represent the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> Ahura Mazda. Similarly, the Mazda
element in the compounds Mazda-dhâta, 'created by Mazda,' Mazda-yasna,
'worshipper of Mazda,' Mazdo-frasasta, 'taught by Mazda,' Mazdo-fraokhta, or
Mazdaokhta, 'spoken by Mazda,' invariably stands for Ahura Mazda himself.
Ahura Mazda is the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> object of worship. Ahura Mazda still holds
sovereign sway over both the worlds; his authority in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of
righteousness is undisputed, and his imperial <span class="t27 hoverable">right</span> is unchallenged. He is the
greatest and the very best of the angels.1 The <span class="t25 hoverable">Old</span> Persian Inscriptions speak
of him as the greatest of the divinities.2 The archangels and angels dutifully
carry out Mazda's orders. Reverence for him has <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> abated, and adoration
of him does not languish with the advent again of the <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span> Indo-Iranian
divinities. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Like</span> the dual divinities Varuna-Mitra who received joint
invocation during the Indo-Iranian period, Ahura-Mithra or Mithra-Ahura
are invoked together. Ahura generally takes precedence and Mithra stands
<span class="t6 hoverable">second</span> in the compound,3 but in the Nyaishes composed in [155] honour of
Hvare Khshaeta or the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> and Mithra, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> in the Yasht dedicated to
Mithra,4 the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> is reversed and we have then Mithra-Ahura. He is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> the
sublimest goal of <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> aspiration. The best of all sacrifices and invocations
are those of Mazda.5 1. Y16.1; Yt17.16.
2. Dar. Pers. d. 1; Xerx. Elv. 1; Xerx. Van. 1.

3. Y1.11; 2.11; 3.13; 4.16; 6.10; 7.13; 17.10; 22.13.
4. Ny1.7; 2.7, 12; Yt10.113, 145.
5. TdFr.28. The faithful acknowledge their indebtedness to Ahura Mazda
and devoutly offer to him their homage and sacrifice.6 They worship him
with the very <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the body,7 and they <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> to reach him through the
medium of fire, through the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> Mind, through Righteousness, and
through the deeds and <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">words</span> of wisdom, as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as through <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> thoughts,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> words, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds.8 Ahura Mazda, in fact, is implored to be their
very <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and limb in both the worlds.9 It is through the Best Righteousness
that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> in <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t19 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">heart</span> aspire to <span class="t0 t5 t16 t22 hoverable">behold</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> to approach him, and to
associate with him,10 The attainment of the companionship and the
Kingdom of Ahura Mazda is the pious wish of the supplicant.11

11. Y40.2; 41.2, 5, 6. Mazda's titles. The Yasna <span class="t27 hoverable">sacrifice</span> opens with the
praise of Ahura Mazda and enumerates the following <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> titles: maker,
radiant, glorious, the greatest, the best, the most beautiful, the most firm, the
most wise, of the most perfect form, the <span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> in righteousness, possessed
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> joy, creator, fashioner, nourisher, and the Most <span class="t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t15 t19 t20 t23 t25 hoverable">Holy</span> Spirit.12 He is
all-pervading. There is no conceivable <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> where he is not. Closer than the
nose is to the ears, or the ears are to the mouth, is he to all that which the
corporeal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> thinks, speaks, and does.13 He is the greatest temporal and
<span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> lord.14 He is the absolute ruler.15 He is the most mighty and
righteous.16 He is benevolent.17 He is the maker, the most holy, the most

wise, and the best <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> to answer when questioned.18 His is the omnisscent
wisdom.19 He is undeceivable.20 He is omniscient and <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> sleeping.21
Radiant and glorious are the most frequent epithets with which the texts
open the invocation to the divinity. [156] Above all Ahura Mazda is the
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of spirits.22 This essential trait stands intact through all changes in the
concept of God. He is not invested with any anthropomorphic chracter, and
his multifarious epithets are truly the figurative expressions of <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span>
language <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> in his feeble attempt to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span> vent to an outburst of the
feelings of devotion and reverence for his Heavenly Father. Ahura Mazda is
synonymous with light, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> as his opponent is identical with darkness, and
the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> is spoken of as his most beautiful form.23 Just as the Rig Veda speaks of
the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> as the eye of Mithra and Varuna,24 so do the Avestan texts call the
<span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> the eye of Ahura Mazda.25 Speaking about the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of Ahuta Mazda,
Plutarch <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> remarks that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> objects of sense the Zoroastrian godhead
most of all resembles the light.26 The star-spangled <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> is his garment;27
the <span class="t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t15 t19 t20 t23 t25 hoverable">holy</span> spell is his soul.28 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Many</span> are the names by which mankind have
learnt to <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">know</span> him. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> Yasht, which is dedicated to him, enumerates
seventy-four of these attributes. They are all descriptive of his wisdom, farsightedness, power, righteousness justice, and mercy.29

Only the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of righteousness is created by Ahura Mazda. As the
antithesis between the Deity and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> is now most strongly marked
in the Later Avesta, the godhead is expressly described as the creator of
everything that is good,30 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> being the counter-creation of Angara Mainyu.
Ahura Mazda and Angra Mainyu in the younger texts are described as
creating <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> in turn. The archangels are Mazda's creations;31 so
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> are the angels and men, the animals, sky, water, trees, light, wind, and
earth.32 In the various enquiries which Zarathushtra addresses to Ahura
Mazda in the Vendidad, the divinity is portrayed as the creator of corporeal
world. Ahura expressly <span class="t1 t7 t9 t14 t15 t17 t25 t28 hoverable">says</span> to Zarathushtra that he has created everything in
[157] the world, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> <span class="t15 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">nothing</span> in his <span class="t14 hoverable">creation</span> comes up to the level of
man, who is the greatest and the best of all creations.33 Through the wisdom
of Ahura Mazda the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> has <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> into being, and through his <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
wisdom it will <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> to an end.34
