[457]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XLIX
PERSIAN <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">WORKS</span> ON ZOROASTRIANISM
Rivayats, or codes of usages and rituals. We have again to <span class="t5 hoverable">pass</span> over a
period of about <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> centuries, or from about the thirteenth century to the

latter <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the fifteenth century, before we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> across a further record of
literary activity. After the convulsions that the small band of fugitives
experienced, they had settled down as the tillers of the fields, sellers of liquor
and toddy, as minor traders and merchants, or as members of petty
professions. By this time, however, the Parsis of Gujarat had begun fairly to
prosper. Some of them had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> succeeded in building up modest fortunes,
and had spread abroad their fame for liberality. This beginning of the
economic welfare of the community shows the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> signs of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> life, and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> these signs was the fact that the community began eagerly to turn its
attention to the necessity of gaining authentic information on the religious
questions about which they were in doubt. The Parsis of India <span class="t0 t5 t6 t14 t18 hoverable">thought</span> that
their co-religionists living in Persia <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> be better informed on religious
matters than themselves, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> have preserved the old-time tradition
more faithfully than they themselves did. They <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> drew up <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span>
religious questions on which they needed enlightenment, and in 1478
commissioned a daring Parsi to go to Persia and lay their questions before
the learned Dasturs of their fatherland. The news that a band of fugitives
lived in India who were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> in faith with them, and shared their common
traditions, had <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> since filtered through to the Zoroastrians of Persia. In
fact it is possible that the connection between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> bands of the faithful,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> imperfect, had <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> been quite broken. Intercourse through trade, as
<span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as other factors, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> have helped to keep up some connection. Great,
therefore, was the enthusiasm caused by the fresh opening of a closer
communication with them; and for nearly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> centuries (1478-1766), a
more immediate interchange of views <span class="t4 hoverable">took</span> <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> between the Zoroastrians of
India and Persia. [458] No less than twenty-two messengers had left India
during this period with questions pertaining to ritual observances,
ceremonial ablutions, purificatory rites, forms of worship, rules of adoption
and marriage and other miscellaneous subjects. These collections of
traditions, customs, and rites, arranged in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of questions and answers,
are composed in Persia, which became the literary language of the Parsi
scholars under the influence of the Moslem rule in Gujarat. These
compilations are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Rivayats, and provide a wealth of information on
liturgical and social matters.1 Side by side with a score of important subjects,
the disquisitions sometimes fall to the level of barren theological
disputations. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Among</span> such discussions, for example, were points <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> these:

Whether the Avestan texts <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be copied with ink prepared by a nonZoroastrian, whether the faithful be polluted by conversing with the nonZoroastrians while they are carrying a dead body, whether a Mobad who has
eaten clarified butter prepared by a non-Zoroastrian can <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> regain bodily
purity by <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> of ceremonial ablutions.
1 The dates of the Persian Rivayats in Studies in Parsi History, by S. H. Hodivala, p.
276-349, Bombay, 1920; Darab Hormazyar's Rivayat, edited by M. R. Unvala,
with an introduction by J. J. Mody, 2 vols; The Persian Rivayats of Hormazyar
Framarz and <span class="t1 t7 t13 hoverable">others</span> by B. N. Dhabhar; Darab Hormazdyar's Rivayat by J. J. Mody,
in the Journal of K. R. Cama Oriental Institute, 23. 109-238. Theology of the
period. Bundahishn and Sad Dar, Jamaspi and Arda Viraf Namah inspired
the clergy and laity in their conduct of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> at this period rather than did the
Gathas and other Avestan works. The formal rather than the spiritual, the
concrete rather than the abstract, seem to be the prominent feature of the
beliefs that we can glean from the Rivayats. The hope of the joys of a
materialized <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and the fear of the sufferings of a physical hell guide and
control man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> earth. Man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and his Farohar are taken, in the
Rivayats, for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> and the same. The souls and not the Farohars are believed
to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> down on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> on their monthly or yearly anniversaries. The souls
of the righteous persons descend on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> and remain here for full ten
<span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t11 t20 t26 t27 hoverable">days</span> of the Farohar festival, but the souls of the wicked ones are <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> only
five days' leave of absence from hell to visit their earthly homes. If the souls
are properly propitiated, they rejoice and bless; if not, they complain and
curse. It <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to be believed that the Yasna sacrifices [459] offered in the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">name</span> of Farohars, or of the angel Hom, or of those of Zartusht, Gushtasp,
and other sainted dead persons, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> thwart the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> designs of their
enemies; <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> rout the demons and fairies; <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> oppose the tyrant kings;
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> withstand famine and plague, retard the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> consequences of bad
dreams, gain favour of kings and noblemen, and secure various advantages.
We are informed, moreover, that the reason of consecrating a <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t15 t17 t18 t19 hoverable">set</span> of white
garments on the fourth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> after <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> is to provide a corresponding
heavenly garment to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> in the next world; because, we are told, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> is quite naked, when it is liberated from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> at death, and is
naturally ashamed to enter the assembly of the heavenly souls who are all
clad in fine raiment. The souls are awarded heavenly garments in proportion

to what is consecrated to them by their kinsmen in this world. The richer the
quality of the garment consecrated here, the finer the raiment bestowed
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> in heaven.
Bull's urine, or golden water, as it is now called, has been an indispensable
article in the purificatory rites and ceremonial ablutions <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the
Zoroastrians from the earliest times. From the strong belief in the efficacy of
its giving external bodily purification, it was but a step to the idea of
attributing to it the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of purifying the internal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of man. A most
extravagant sanctity <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to be attached to the drinking of it. Elaborate
rituals are now performed over the liquid and the drinking of this
consecrated fluid <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> an indissoluble <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span> Zoroastrian
ceremonials. The Rivayats tell us that the drink gives <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> glory, and makes
man's inner <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> as bright and as pure as the sun.
Bull's urine has been, since ancient times, an essential auxiliary of spells or
formulas <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> to exorcise those possessed by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> power; but the original
Avestan and Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">word</span> gaomaeza or gomez fell into disuse by the Rivayat
time, and the term nirang, which originally meant spell only, now signifies
both spell and bull's urine, and henceforth conveys both the meanings. Such
in general is the view that we gather from the Rivayats regarding the
conditions prevailing in that period.
Other <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> in Persian. Besides the Rivayats, several works, both in prose
and in verse, have reached us. The most important of these is the Zartusht
Namah or <span class="t25 hoverable">Book</span> of Zartusht composed in <span class="t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">verse</span> by Zartusht Bahram Pazdu in the
thirteenth [460] century.2 The account of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the prophet is based
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the Pahlavi works. Several Pahlavi <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> are rendered into Persian. The
Avestan texts are translated into Persian with the help of their Pahlavi
version. A considerable devotional literature and treatises on miscellaneous
subjects are extant. There are about forty short prayers in <span class="t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">verse</span> and gazal
form, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Monâjâts composed by about a dozen <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> priests. The
earliest in point of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> are the four hymns attributed to the authorship of
Zartusht Bahram Pazdu, the author of the Zartusht Namah. The latest are
composed in the third quarter of the last century.

p. 477-522; Rosenberg, Le Livre de Zoroaster.

<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> L
MYSTICS AND MYSTICISM
To <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">know</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is the dictum of mysticism. Religions
have looked to <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> revelation as the real source of <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> wisdom. The
faculties of the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> mind, it is believed by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of mystic temperament,
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of God. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Knowledge</span> gathered through the
senses is illusive. Reason is not capable of comprehending God. To attempt
to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">see</span> him through the medium of reason is to lose him. Intuition is higher
than reason. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> reason <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> conduct the adept to the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> portal,
intuition alone can enable him to penetrate into the sanctuary and have a
vision of God. <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Human</span> <span class="t20 hoverable">intelligence</span> is debarred from entering this inner
sphere. <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> wisdom dawns <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> when it renounces its own
thoughts and reflection, and loses all self-consciousness. In such an entirely
passive and receptive state of ecstasy, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> is divinely illumined. It is the
outcome of immediate contact of the pure <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> with God. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> that
yearns to <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">know</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> seek its union with the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> mind. The
transcendental insight gives a supra-rational apprehension of <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> wisdom.
<span class="t3 t7 t9 t10 t15 t19 t22 hoverable">Truth</span> dawns <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> him, and shines in its effulgence, while an ecstatic
insight is aroused in him and in a moment of ecstasy, when the devotee
transcends all self-consciousness, the wave of the occult <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> surges in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
him, and the mysterious something sweeps, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> a meteor, over his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span>
giving a sudden flash that illumines the inner world. The nightingale in its
transport of joy sings to the glory of God, until it becomes half frenzied.
When the mystic is bathed in devotion, he is so intoxicated with the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
wisdom that he thinks himself <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> with the Divine. In this condition the
devotee does not meditate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> God, he feels him; he does not think of
God, he owns him.
The allegorical method of interpreting religious texts. From very early
times some theologians of both the East and the West [462] have maintained
that the prophets adapt themselves to the mode of thinking of the masses
and use parables and legends to express their views. The sacred texts, they

say, are <span class="t23 hoverable">written</span> in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> which contains a double meaning, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> is the
surface meaning, which can be understood by the masses, and the other is
the inner or hidden <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span> meant for the initiated. The Sophists and Stoics
resorted to the method of allegorically interpreting Greek mythology to
meet the attacks of sceptical criticism. The Alexandrian Jewish and Christian
theologians, Philo and Origen, spoke of the literal and <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> meanings of
the sacred books. The first, they wrote, was the bodily <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the <span class="t2 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t20 t24 t29 hoverable">text</span> meant
for the majority and the <span class="t6 hoverable">second</span> was its <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> which was understood
by those few who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> find the revealed kernel, hidden by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> in the outer
textual shell. The Gnostics and the Neo-Platonists <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> attempted to explain
Oriental and Occidental myths by allegorical interpretation. The Ismailis,
the Sect of the Seven and other schools that flourished in Iran from the ninth
century, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> themselves the Bâtinis or the esoterics as opposed to the
Zâhiris or the exoterics or literalists. Their method of interpreting the sacred
texts on the allegorical basis is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> tâ’wil.
This method of interpreting religious texts persists throughout the various
periods of the history of the religions of the world. Legends and myths,
traditional dogmas and superstitious customs, historical errors and textual
discrepancies, primitive beliefs and practices are all invested with the
mysterious meanings. Statements which often repel both <span class="t20 hoverable">intelligence</span> and
conscience find an easy expedient in allegory. The esoterics generally seek in
the sacred texts what their own thinking is willing to find and read in them
what is rooted in their minds. They read the subjective <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span> into the
texts and draw unwarranted implications from them. Forces of nature,
animate or inanimate objects are all <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span> and explained as
symbolizing some ethical idea, some aspects of man's consciousness, some
expression of the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> in man. Rational explanations are attempted for
apparently absurd customs to preserve them against rational criticism.
Symbolic significance is attached to puerile legends. Unbridled by the
canons of reason and undeterred by any regard for historical sense and
critical acumen, the esoteric interpreters of religions generally produce
allegorizing extravagances.
[463] Desatir and Dabistan. In the early <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the last century appeared
the <span class="t2 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t20 t24 t29 hoverable">text</span> and translation of the Desatir, alleged to have a heavenly origin, and
to have been <span class="t23 hoverable">written</span> down in the reign of Khusru Parviz and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> to throw a

flood of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> on Zoroastrianism. A very heated controversy was the result of
the appearance of this work. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">One</span> party of eminent European scholars
declared it to be a fraudulent forgery, while <span class="t1 t7 t13 hoverable">others</span> of equal eminence
endeavoured to prove its authenticity. The claim of the Desatir to have been
<span class="t23 hoverable">written</span> in a celestial language was <span class="t0 t2 t16 t18 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">put</span> to a crucial test. Patient research has
since declared the <span class="t25 hoverable">book</span> to be an exotic, outside the pale of Zoroastrianism.
And so it has been held by all Iranian scholars both of East and West.1
1 Bharucha, in Zartoshti, vol. 3, p.121-134;179-191; vol.4, p.257-279,
Bombay, 1275 A. Y.
In this <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> are <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> the teachings of various mystic schools, and the entire
treatise breathes a totally <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> atmosphere from that of the genuine
Zoroastrian works, being divergent in tone from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> from its very
beginning to its close. The Iranian scriptures of all periods have recognized
Gayomard as the primeval man, who was the progenitor of the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> race,
and who, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> mortals, heard the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">word</span> of Ohrmazd.1a But this
work, on the contrary, gives a regular hierarchy of prophets who are
supposed to have preceded the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> man. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> revealed his secrets to
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> Mahabad, who was followed by thirteen other prophets in the former
cycles of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> bearing his name. Through them the supposed revelation
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> down to Gayomard and his descendants. It is alleged in this book,
moreover, that all the early Pishdadian kings conformed to this religion of
Mahabad, until the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> that Zoroaster <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> and preached his
fundamentally <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> religion. But <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> prophet's religion, we are told,
was so glossed over by the Yazdanians, the followers of Mahabad, that
Zoroastrianism was ultimately <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> to confer to the Mahabadian code.2
1a Yt. 13.87. 2 Dabistan, tr. Shea and Troyer, vol. 1, p. 30.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Another</span> Persian <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> entitled Dabistan, or School of Manners, <span class="t23 hoverable">written</span> in
India by Mohsan Fani in the seventeenth century, draws the greater <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of
its materials from the Desatir. The author of this composition mentions some
fourteen sects into which he finds the Zoroastrians of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> divided. These
are the Sipasian, Abadian, Jamshaspian, Samradian, Khodaiyan, [464]
Radian, Shidrangian, Paikarian, Milanian, Alarian, Shidabian, Akhshiyan,
Zardushtian, and Mazdakian. Several of these sects are stated to have
flourished from very remote times, going back to the Pahlavi and Avestan
periods, nay stretching <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> back to a period of which history has not a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">word</span> to tell. With the exception of these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> works, however, we have no

inkling of other sects in the genuine Iranian texts. The statements contained
in them are not corroborated by any authority in the writings of the
Zoroastrian priests. They do not mention them by name, they are entirely
unaware of their existence. The account of the majority of these sects, as
<span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> in the Dabistan, is very meagre. We meet with some attempts in them
to explain the primordial principle from which <span class="t14 hoverable">creation</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> into being, and
we have some sort of crude metaphysics grafted on physics. Sun, fire, air,
nature, water, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> are alternately <span class="t0 t2 t16 t18 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">put</span> forward as having been the
physical sources of existence <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">according</span> to various schools of thinkers.3
<span class="t1 t7 t13 hoverable">Others</span> still preach a strict monism, and assume that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of phenomena
was caused by illusion.4 The teachings of the Yazdanians and <span class="t1 t7 t13 hoverable">others</span> are
characterized by a belief in metempsychosis, as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as in the efficiency of
rigorous austerities and ascetic virtues. Our present concern, however, is
with the author's account of the Zoroastrian mystics, and we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> now turn
to the matter immediately.
3 Vol. 1, p. 202-207.
4 Ib., p. 195.
Zoroastrian mystics. At this period we meet with some Parsi thinkers who
were not satisfied with the formal side of religion, and looked with
indifference <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the ritual observances, Outward formalism and literal
interpretation of the teachings of the prophet failed to meet with the
longings of these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of mystic temperament. They <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> remained in search
of mysteries hidden beneath the outward garb of dogmas and rituals. The
Parsi priesthood <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> not satisfy the wants of such ecstatic enthusiasts.
They revolted from authority, and <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t15 t17 t18 t19 hoverable">set</span> about thinking for themselves. These
dissenters as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> lived a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> from that led by their neighbours.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Many</span> of them <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> consolation in the teachings of the Hindu Yogis and
became their willing disciples. Under these circumstances we have to turn to
the Dabistan for the general information of this sect, as the historic Parsi
<span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> are silent over the question and do not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> notice its existence.
[465] Azar Kaivan and his disciples. The author of the Dabistan gives us an
elaborate account of the Zoroastrian mystics whom he met in Patna, in
Kashmir, and in Lahore during the seventeenth century.5 The most illustrious
of these mystic teachers was Dastur Azar Kaivan who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> from Persia and

settled in Patna,6 and lived for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> in seclusion <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">far</span> from the public gaze.7
Some of the most prominent disciples of this recluse sage were the Mobads
Farzan Bahram of Shiraz, Hushiyyar of Surat, Sarosh, and Khuda Jui. They
extravagantly trace their lineage back to Ma-habad, to Sam, Godrej, Rustam,
Jamasp, Zoroaster, and Noshirvan. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Let</span> us now <span class="t5 hoverable">pass</span> on to a brief notice of the
literary activity of these hermit priests.
5 Vol. 1, 108, 115, 118, 119, 122, 123; vol. 3, 204. 6 Vol. 1, 89.
7 Vol. 1, 93.
Mystic literature during the period. These Parsi mystics composed several
treatises in Persian, which, as we have already seen, was the literary medium
of this period. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Among</span> the more important <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> that have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> down
to us are Jam-i Kaikhusru, Makashefat-i Kaivani, Khishtab, Zaredasht Afshar,
and Zindah Rud. The author of the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> allege that their <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> are
translations into Persian from the original Pahlavi books <span class="t23 hoverable">written</span> in the <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t11 t20 t26 t27 hoverable">days</span>
of the Sasanian kings Hormazd and Khusru Parviz. A search through the
literary content of these writings, however, shows that their philosophical
dissertations mostly reproduce the teachings of Greek philosophy, current in
India in the seventeenth century through its Arabic version. For instance, the
Khishtab opens with the prophet Mahabad's descriptions of the four
generative principles of things, which are <span class="t15 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">nothing</span> else but the material,
formal, efficient, and final causes of Aristotle. The authors fantastically credit
the legendary and real kings and princes of Persia with the philosophical
ideas, which on very little examination can easily be traced to their original
Greek sources. These royal personages are styled prophets or seers and
depicted as advancing some original argument for the proof of the existence
of God, his eternal attributes, and regarding other kindred subjects. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Even</span> the
warrior heroes Zal and Rustam seem occasionally to have proclaimed a truce
to warfare, and to have devoutly sat down in more peaceful pursuit of
metaphysical investigations; for some of the philosophical disquisitions stand
in their names too.
[466] The alleged twofold <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span> of the Avesta. These esoteric
interpreters of the sacred <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> asserted that Zoroaster had couched his
teachings in figurative and enigmatic language.8 The Zoroastrian scriptures
were accordingly divided into 'Great Zend' and 'Little Zend,'9 the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> being
followed by the adepts and initiates, and the <span class="t6 hoverable">second</span> by the masses.. The

figurative language of the former hid the deeper truths from the ignorant.
8 Db., <span class="t14 hoverable">vol</span> 1.361.
9 Ib., 352.
The author, then, cites some instances and explains the difference between
the exoteric and the esoteric interpretations of the Avestan texts. For
instance; when it is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> that the archangel Bahman held a conference with
Zoroaster and asked him to close his eyes, the vulgar, <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">according</span> to the
Dabistan, understand that Bahman assumed <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> and addressed the
prophet <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> a mortal; but the adept is to understand by this that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span>
essence of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> was uncompounded, and that under such a state Bahman
manifested himself before Zoroaster, and his asking the prophet to close his
eyes <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> only that the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> asked him to eradicate all bodily attachment
and suppress carnal desires of the flesh in <span class="t0 t6 t7 t8 t11 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to enable him to get a vision
of the archangel.10 When the Zoroastrian texts seem to sanction animal
slaughter, it is to be understood as an injunction to kill the animal
propensities inherent in man.11 The author states further that the passages
which speak of the hermits as partaking of animal food in reasonable bounds
are not to be <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> literally. These simply refer to the gradual control and
ultimate killing of the animal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> in man.12 The legend that Ahriman
appeared at a season festival in the guise of a glutton and devoured
everything to the utter confusion of the assembly, until he was routed by
preparing a dish from the flesh of a <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span> red cow, mixed with vinegar,
garlic, and rue, at the instance of some miraculous advice, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> by
the masses as literally true. But any <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> versed in esoteric wisdom, and
acquained with the doctrines inculcated by the Dabistan, knows that the
killing of the red cow stands for the suppression of the sensual appetite,
vinegar for the virtue of abstinence, garlic for reflection, and rue for silent
reflection. All these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> kill Ahrimanian propensities in man.13 The
ignorant invest Ahriman with a personality; but, really [467] speaking, he has
no independent existence, for he is not an entity and is simply the negation
of existence.14 The aggregate of bodily passions and sensual appetites is
symbolically termed Ahriman, named from the originator of evil,15 and
Ahriman's predominance in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is to exist only for a limited <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> while
the tumult of youth in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> and the bodily passions in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> are in the
ascendency and until they are ultimately curbed and eradicated.16 Again, the
sacred books speak of Ahriman as the creator of serpents and scorpions. But

these noxious creatures, <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">according</span> to this treatise, are <span class="t15 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">nothing</span> but allegorical
expressions for the vices and passions that haunt the <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t7 t11 t12 t13 t14 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> mind.17 All such
persons as stick to the exoteric interpretation of the scriptures believe that
Zohak actually carried <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> serpents on his shoulders, but the adept
understand the statement as applying to the venomous tyranny and
sensuality of the wicked usurper.18 The legend of the flight of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Kaus to
the heavens, his fall, and the subsequent restoration of this lost monarch to
his kingdom by Rustam, has likewise an esoteric interpretation. The four
eagles that carried the misguided <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> high up in the air, along with his
throne, signify the four elements. The throne, explains the author, stands for
the predominant bodily passions, the ascent <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> that a devotee can rise to
a higher plane of existence by a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of abstinence and austerity, the fall
denotes the revolt of the passions owing to some neglect in the observance
of the ascetic practices, :while Rustam's achievement, in finally bringing
Kaus back from the forest, indicates the flash of proper <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> that
reclaims the erring aspirant from fatal mishap.19 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> the esoteric writings
veil the <span class="t3 t7 t9 t10 t15 t19 t22 hoverable">truth</span> from the gaze of the vulgar. The real and deep <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span> is
hidden <span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> the: outer husks; and only he who grasps this inner <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span>
can attain to insight into the secret doctrine. This in fact is a summary of the
mystic teachings of the Parsi ascetics in the Dabistan, based evidently <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
the earlier doctrines of Sufism and developed under Hindu mystic influences
in India.

Ascetic practices of the Parsi mystics. The hermits practised celibacy.20

They abstained from animal food,21 and reduced the quantity of their daily
food, until <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> of them <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> live on [468] food weighing ten dirhams, or a
fraction of an ounce, a day22 or in some cases on only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> such unit.23 Some
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> live <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any kind of food or drink for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t11 t20 t26 t27 hoverable">days</span> in
succession.24 Such devotees practised <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> kinds of austerities;25 and all of
these mortifications of the flesh were undergone in religious imitation of
their Hindu brethren. The chief <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> such austerities were those of
supporting themselves on the extremities of their fingers from midnight until
dawn,26 and of standing on the head with the feet raised in the air from
nightfall <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> sunrise.27 By rigorous discipline some such religious
enthusiasts, we are told, attained the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of suppressing their breath for
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> hours,28 or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> for twelve.29 They <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> swoon <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span> into a state
of trance,30 in which respiration and breathing were totally suspended and by
this utter self-abnegation the adepts reached the borders of utter selflessness.
Mobad Hushiyyar, once plunged into deep <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and remained underneath
for full six hours before he raised his head above the surface.31 These
devotees, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> the Indian Yogis, as shown below, are credited with the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span>
of quitting the bodily frame at pleasure, traversing the <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> regions, and
returning to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> whenever they liked.32 They laid claim to read the
thoughts of others.33 They are further fantastically credited with the
superhuman <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of performing miracles; such as causing the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> to hide
his disk and appear at night, or the stars to appear during the day, walking
on the surface of water, showing themselves in the <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of lightning in the
heavens, metamorphosing animals, rendering themselves invisible to man,
assuming various forms,34 appearing at <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> and the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> at distant
places, bringing the dead to life, or causing the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> of the living,
producing food and wine from nothing,35 causing the rains to fall or to cease,
producing giants to frighten others, converting broken pottery into gold,36
disporting in the midst of a burning fire, or swallowing it,37 and such like.

[469] Unmistakable influence of Hindu Yogism. All this self-mortification
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the assumption of occult powers sounds unfamiliar to
Zoroastrian ears. The <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> fabric of the ascetic and unworldly view of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
is in direct antagonism to the active, and, in the best sense, worldly <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
the Mazdayasnian faith. In its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> detail, as indicated above, the Parsi
mystic school savours of the strong influence of the Indian Yogis. The Parsi
ascetics of the period seem to have been in close acquaintance with the
Hindu hermits. The author of the Dabistan informs us that Mobad
Hushiyyar conducted him to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">see</span> some of these Hindu ascetics,38 and he
speaks equally of Parsi adepts who were in constant touch with such Hindu
monks.39 He further mentions a Parsi ascetic who moved about in Gujarat
clad in the garments of a Hindu hermit,40 and who visited the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Sikh
saint, Guru Har Govind.41 Hirbad, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Parsi mystic, moreover, gave
instructions to his disciple, Mobad Hushiyyar, either to burn or bury his
body, when dead,42 because it mattered not whether a corpse was consigned
to the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> or to the earth.43 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Every</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> of its details shows the total
indifference on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of these dissenters to what was really <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> of
Zoroastrian observance.

[470]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LI
RELIGIOUS CONTROVERSIES
Theological disputations. We find from the extent Persian literature that the
writers of this period occupied themselves in minute quibbling and barren
discussions of the ritualistic ceremonies and purificatory rites. There is no
trace of original thinking on vital problems. Their energy was wholly
expended on endless wranglings about dogmas and theological disquisitions.
Questions were raised whether it was essential to cover the face of a corpse
with the penom, or mouth-covering white veil; whether the legs of a corpse
should be folded or left lengthwise, before it was removed to its final resting
place.1 The community was actually divided into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> parties over the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span>
question, and so bitter was the feeling aroused that at Surat the corpses <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> such coverings were refused a resting-place in the Tower of Silence. The
relatives of the dead had under these circumstances to carry dead bodies to
Navsari for their final disposal. This resulted in the erection of separate
towers for the contending parties.
1. Patell, Parsi Prakash, 1, 23, Bombay, 1888. Intercalation controversy
provides a powerful incentive to the study of the ancient Zoroastrian
scriptures. In 1720 were planted seeds of a controversy' which gave,
however, a real and abiding impetus to religious studies. A learned Mobad
named Jamasp, who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to India from Persia, in 1721, <span class="t0 t16 t25 t28 hoverable">found</span> that the Indian
Parsis were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> month behind the Zoroastrians of Persia in the calculation of
their year, and he strongly advocated a reform in the matter. The question at
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> did not arouse <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> attention, but later it developed into a serious
problem that led to a display of strong passion and to the exchange of bitter
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">words</span> on both sides in the community. Learned priests in each party
zealously turned to the study of the original scriptures, as a source to decide
the matter, and the question was threshed out in detail, accompanied by the
publication of innumerable tracts [471]and pamphlets. While the learned in
the community were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> engaged in ransacking their ancient records, the
masses <span class="t4 hoverable">took</span> up the controversy acrimoniously, resorting to abuses and sometimes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> to blows. The Shahinshahis, or the Imperials, represented the <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span>

order, and the dissenters styled themselves the Kadimis, or the Ancients. The
former annoyed the latter by their mocking derision. Social intercourse
between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> became most strained, the community was split into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
sects, and separate places of worship were founded. The division of the
community into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> sects endures to the present day, but despite the
differences obtaining between the two, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> and the growth of education
have obliterated the bitter feelings. Modern researches have proved that
both the parties were wrong in their calculations. The accidentals of the
controversy have changed during the <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> period of hard-fought battles, but
the main question has still remained as unsettled as before. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Among</span> the chief
causes that have contributed to the indefinite postponement of the reform
are the indifference and apathy of the community. The question is looked at
with misgivings, as not falling in the arena of practical reform, because
fraught with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> complications. What we are more concerned with is, that
the controversy gave <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> to literary activities, and encouraged studious
habits <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the learned.
[472]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LII
AN EPOCH-MAKING ERA IN THE HISTORY OF ZOROASTRIAN
RESEARCHES
Introduction of Iranian studies in the West. The inexorable decree of
Providence had ruled that a <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> from the West should dispel the
darkness that had surrounded the pages of the sacred scriptures for ages, and
add to their better understanding and elucidation. European travellers who
had visited India and Persia during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries
acquainted the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of the West with the religious beliefs, manners, and
customs of the followers of Zoroaster. Hyde's masterly <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> on Parsi
religion, which drew its materials from the <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> of the classical authors and
the Persian version of the Sad Dar as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as from kindred works, appeared in
1700. Some important Iranian manuscripts had been carried from India to
England, and were now shelved as curios in the Bodleian library at Oxford.
Anquetil du Perron's pioneer work. To the energetic Frenchman, Anquetil

du Perron, is due the credit of making the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> systematic attempt to study
the Avestan texts and <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> their contents before the Western world.1
Having <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> across a facsimile of four leaves of the Bodleian manuscript, his
curiosity was aroused, and with characteristic zeal he enlisted as a soldier in
1754 on a ship bound for India with the aim of bringing back to the Western
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of the sacred scriptures of Zoroaster. Unbounded
enthusiasm, combined with the vigour of youth, enabled Anquetil to
overcome the almost insuperable difficulties that stood in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of his
literary enterprise. Having acquired from Dastur Darab, the High Priest of
the Parsis of Surat, what inadequate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> get in those days,
he returned home after six <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> of strenuous <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> and published the result
of his studies in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> quarto volumes in 1771. This [473]publication created
a stir in literary circles, and gave rise to a heated controversy. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">One</span> school of
<span class="t0 t5 t6 t14 t18 hoverable">thought</span> of eminent scholars in Europe declined to attach any weight to the
Frenchman's work, and denied that the grotesque stuff that he had placed
before the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> be the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> a thinker and sage as
Zoroaster, stoutly maintaining that Anquetil's Avesta was either a forgery or
that he had been duped by the Indian Parsi Mobads. The falseness of this
view, however, was ultimately shown.
1. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">See</span> Mody, Anquetil du Perron and Dastur Darab, Bombay, 1916. Western
scholarship revives Zoroastrian studies. The disinterested labours of various
scholars during the subsequent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> fully substantiated Anquetil's pioneer
work; and when the closer affinity between the languages of the Avesta and
Sanskrit became generally known, the sacred texts began to be studied in the
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of comparative philology, and the authenticity of the Avesta was
completely proved. The seeds sown by Anquetil have since blossomed into
fruitful trees in the West, but some decades passed after the publication of
his <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> before Western scholarship penetrated into India.
[474]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LIII
PROSELYTIZING COMES TO BE VIEWED WITH DISFAVOUR

Beginning of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of exclusiveness <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the Parsis.We have already
seen that the handful of the Parsi fugitives who emigrated to India after the
final overthrow of the Persian empire in the middle of the seventh century
had to face enormous difficulties in the earlier centuries of their settlement in
the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> home. The precarious condition in which they lived for a considerable period <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> it impracticable for them to keep up their former
proselytizing zeal. The instinctive fear of disintegration and absorption in
the vast multitudes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> whom they lived created in them a <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
exclusiveness and a strong feeling for the preservation of the racial
characteristics and distinctive features of their community. Living in an
atmosphere surcharged with the Hindu caste system, they felt that their own
safety lay in encircling their fold by rigid caste barriers.
The community was divided regarding the question of admitting lower
classes of aliens into its fold. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> the practice of an active religious
propaganda had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> fallen into desuetude, the question of conversion does
not seem to have died out entirely, for we find recorded in the Rivayat
literature that a heated polemic regarding the subject was carried on during
the latter <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the eighteenth century. With the beginning of economic
prosperity, the Indian Parsis, we learn, were in the habit of purchasing male
and female slaves of low Hindu castes. These slaves, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> cases, were
invested with sacred shirt and girdle and admitted into the Zoroastrian fold
by the priests at the request of their masters. Those members of the
community who were opposed to the mingling of their blood with that of
such a low class of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> denied to these converts the full privileges of a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> believer. The contesting parties applied to their coreligionists in Persia
for their advice and decision in the matter. The point <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> by those who
favoured the <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span> of the [475]the converts was that the Parsis of India who
owned slaves for their <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> not only often had them admitted to the
Mazdayasnian faith in accordance with the tenets of the religion, but also,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> and religious scruples, partook of food prepared by them, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span>
permitted them, at the season festival to prepare the sacred cakes <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> for
consecration and sacrificial purposes. It was urged that having allowed the
converted slaves all such rights of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Zoroastrian in their lifetime, <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span>
priests as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as laymen objected to the corpses of these slaves being
deposited in the Tower of Silence when they died. The Iranian high priests,
in replying to their inquiring brothers in India advised them in the beginning

to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">take</span> precautionary measures in all such conversions that no harm should
thereby be done to the religion and to the community. It was certainly an act
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> merit, they proceeded, to purchase alien <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">children</span> and <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> them up
as Zoroastrians. It was unfair and highly objectionable, they added, nay it
was an inexpiable sin, to refuse these unfortunate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> all the privileges of
a believer after once admitting them into the Zoroastrian religious fold. It is
taught by the scriptures, they argued, that all mankind will be <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> over
to the religion of Mazda in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of the future saviour prophets. It was,
