therefore, the pious duty of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Zoroastrian to help this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t1 t3 t9 t15 t20 t21 t26 t29 hoverable">cause</span> by
leading all to the path of righteousness. In the face of such commands, they
concluded, those who denied to the proselytes the full rights of a faithful
believer did not deserve to be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Zoroastrians. On <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">another</span> occasion in
reply to a question about the conversion of such low-class people, the
Iranian informant wrote that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who dug graves or followed the
profession of burning the dead (two inexpiable sins <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">according</span> to
Zoroastrianism), should be admitted into the Zoroastrian fold, provided his
admittance <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not be harmful to the faith.
The fear that the community <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t18 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">might</span> be swamped by the undesirable alien
element was a reason why proselytizing fell into disfavour. We notice in
that discussion that the <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> sections of the community were divided
more on the social side of the question of proselytizing than on its religious
side. The protest was chiefly based against the admixture of racial blood that
the low class of the aliens introduced into the community. The Zoroastrians
of Persia, who were trampled under the iron [476]foot of their Moslem
conquerors and had lived in servile state, saw no objection whatsoever in
receiving converts <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> from the lowest strata of the non-Zoroastrian
peoples. But the case was <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> with the Indian Parsis, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> whom the
improved social and economic conditions had aroused a keen sense of racial
pride and consciousness of their past greatness. A very considerable portion
of the community, it seems, looked with disapproval <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the introduction
of the undesirable element of alien races into their small numbers. This
strong feeling was aggravated the more through the fact that such converts
who sought admission <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> always from the lowest classes. Members of the
upper classes of the non-Zoroastrian communities were not heard knocking
at the door of the Mazdayasnian fire-temples seeking admission. The

community was not disposed to any kind of active religious propaganda. The
cases of conversion were consequently confined either to the slaves <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span>
up in Parsi families or to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">children</span> born to Parsi fathers of their nonZoroastrian mistresses. Proselytizing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to be associated with the low type
of foreign element, and fell into disrepute. A beginning of opposition to the
idea of religious propaganda was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> when the entire question of
proselytizing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to be looked <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> by the community with disfavour. No
serious attempt has since been <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> by the Parsis of India to organize a
proselytizing movement with the sole object of propagating their faiths But
the desire on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of some Zoroastrians to include in the faith <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">children</span>
born to them by illegitimate intercourse with non-Zoroastrian mistresses, or
by <span class="t1 t7 t13 hoverable">others</span> seeking a matrimonial alliance with alien women and investing the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">children</span> born of such unions with the sacred shirt and girdle, has prompted
them to open the question from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to the present day. So bitter
have been the controversies <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> arising that they have stopped just short of
physical violence.
[477]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LIV
GUJARATI LITERATURE BEARING <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">UPON</span> ZOROASTRIANISM
The last native version of the Avesta independent of the influence of
Western scholarship. So <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">far</span> the Parsi scholars had generally <span class="t23 hoverable">written</span> in the
Persian language, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of which was limited to a very narrow circle,
and the general public accordingly did not profit by their work. The need
had <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> been felt of producing theological literature in the language of the
people, and several portions of the Persian Rivayats had already been done
into Gujarati. These were followed during the early <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the last century
by a Gujarati version of the Avestan texts, not from the original, but based
on the Pahlavi, Sanskrit, and Persian renderings. This was the last native
attempt to render the Avestan scriptures into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">another</span> language through the
medium of the Pahlavi translation. The Sanskrit, Persian, and Gujarati
translators had all successively <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> their renderings on the basis of the
traditional Pahlavi version; it was left for the modern philologists to
approach the Avestan texts in the original itself, independently of the

Pahlavi rendering <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> aided by it, and through the methods of strict
linguistic science to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">give</span> an independent and first-hand translation of the
original Avestan texts. Rendering of other Persian <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> into Gujarati. The
Persian Zartusht Namah was rendered into <span class="t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">verse</span> in Gujarati by Mobad
Rustam Peshutan Hamajiar in the early <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the eighteenth century1. The
Gujarati version of the Avesta was soon followed by a translation of some of
the important Pazand-Persian <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> into Gujarati. The most popular <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span>
these were Jamaspi and Arda Viraf Namah. The prognostications of the
former treatise fascinated the gentler sex, who were regaled by the recital of
its contents from the lips of the family priest, [478]or of some male member
of the family who happened to <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">know</span> the language. Viraf's account of the
beatific visions of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and the horrors of hell appeared in illustrated
lithographed editions. The pictures of the heavenly persons seated on golden
thrones, and of the wicked falling headlong into hell to be gnawed by
noxious creatures, served vividly to <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> the abstract ethical teachings,
before the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> of young and old. Some devotional literature, both in prose
and verse, appeared during this period. In the same connection, it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be
added that the episodes of the Persian kings and warriors, handed down from
antiquity by tradition, were rendered into Gujarati, and were most enthusiastically read or heard by all. This helped to <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> home to them the greatness
and glory of their ancestors.
1 Meherbanu and Behramgore Anklesaria's Zartosht Namun, Bombay, 1932.
[479]

A PERIOD OF REVIVAL
NINETEENTH CENTURY AND AFTER

[480 is blank]
[481]

CHAPTER LV
MODERNISM VERSUS TRADITIONALISM
The modern <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is divided between Modernism and Traditionalism.
Religions rest on <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> revelation. This revealed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> is static. Secular
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> progresses with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> and, by continuous research and discovery
in the realm of the physics of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> and the laws of life, creates <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span>
knowledge. It knows no <span class="t7 t10 t15 t25 hoverable">end</span> and is <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> new. It adapts itself to the times and
satisfies the cravings of the thinking minds. From the earliest times, religion
spoke with authority on matters relating to the spirit. But there were physical
problems for which the inquisitive <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> always demanded solution. Science
claimed to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> discoveries in the realm of physical researches.
Religion adopted science as its handmaid and incorporated the discoveries of
the scientists and the physicists and proclaimed them as the further <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
revelation to mankind to explain physical questions. The crude cosmologies
and cosmogonies of the times when science was in its infancy were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> integral parts of the religions of the world. The researches of modern
science have rendered them untenable in the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of advanced knowledge.
The doctrine of evolution has revolutionized man's outlook <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
throughout the world. Modern science has changed the attitude of the
thinking <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> everywhere. The intellectual ferment and <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> unrest
have stirred the <span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> world. The enlightened youths are driven to disbelief.
They are not happy in the state of disbelief. They are anxious to believe and
secure peace of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> but they <span class="t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">cannot</span> honestly subscribe to the beliefs in
which they are <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> up. They are disbelievers despite themselves. This
state of disbelief is produced by honest doubt.
Orthodoxy is obstinacy to forget anything <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span> and learn anything new.
Orthodoxy has always and everywhere professed that the doctrines, dogmas,
rituals, and the established views of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> that a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> has inherited are fixed
and right. All those that dissent from them are heterodox, other than right,
not right, [482]that is, wrong. Orthodoxy has always numbers on its side, for
the average <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is temperamentally timid and conservative and is unwilling
to be disturbed in the thoughts and views he has inherited with his birth. He
seeks refuge in tradition and is content to live secure in the dead past. All
that is handed down from remote times and forms the tradition of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>

is sacred. Orthodoxy is jealous of the views it holds and resents all
opposition to them. It aims at making <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> religious in its own way. It
moves about with prying eyes and spies on its neighbour's conscience and
struggles to read his thoughts. Whenever it is powerful enough to inflict its
will <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> others, it clips the wing of thought, gags speech, and cripples
action. The collective orthodox <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> controls the thinking of the individual
and drives the dissenters to secrete their thoughts in the lowest depths of
their souls. Orthodoxy makes free thinking taboo and fails to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">see</span> that high
thinking is impossible <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> free thinking. Orthodoxy is impervious to the
influence of the times.
[483]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LVI
THE REVIVAL OF LEARNING <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">AMONG</span> THE PARSIS
Awakening of the communal conscience. The advent of the British in India,
and an era of peace, justice, and security of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and property, ushered in by
them, opened a <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> page in the history of the Parsis. Having a ready scope,
the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> of adaptation, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> elasticity in their religion, they now began
to assert their latent capacity, and soon emerged from the obscurity in which
they had lived, to <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> henceforth the foremost <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in India in matters
educational, industrial, and social. They <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> in the vanguard of progress,
amassed vast fortunes, and munificently gave <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span> large sums in charity.
This unprecedented economic prosperity helped the revival of learning
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the Zoroastrians. The <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> epoch of the revival of learning gave <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span>
hopes for a period of formation and life. Various educational institution had
been founded, and the Parsis faced the problem of the responsibility of
universal franchise in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of letters. The average Parsi child of both the
sexes entered the schools founded on European lines by the community
during the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> half of the last century, in various centres of Parsi population,
and education on Western standards spread with accelerated rapidity.
The <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> profoundly modified the religious conceptions of the
young. The inroads of Western ideas and culture undermined the <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span> ideals,
and modified <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> of the beliefs sanctified by ages. It was the opening of a
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> age for the Parsis, in which they witnessed the waning of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of

authority and the waxing of the demand for the verification of religious
truths. The transition from the <span class="t25 hoverable">old</span> to the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> was bound to be disruptive.
The <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> that had <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> hold of the community stirred it to its lowest
depth. It threatened the community with an intellectual revolt from the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span>
school. The reaction was bound to come, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">come</span> it did. It was violent as
all reaction is apt to be, and it ended in indifferentism. The [484]popular
creed as propounded by the traditionalist exponents and orthodox formalists
failed to carry conviction to their intellect. They wanted to verify their
doubts and refused to believe that which, as they said, was not in accord
with reason. The glowing accounts of the reward and retribution of the
materialized <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and hell ceased to act <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the imagination of the
educated classes. The imaginings of Viraf failed to exert any restraining
influence over the tendency to sin. The inspired visions of this seer, about
the scenes of the hereafter, depicting the pleasures of the souls of the blessed
in paradise and the agonies of the wicked in hell, which satisfied the <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span>
cravings of their elders for ages, failed longer so to do in the case of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span>
generation. The waters of Ardvisur had inundated the regions of hell and
quenched the blazing fire, the horrors of hell had vanished into thin air, and
the apocalyptic account of Viraf no longer presented to the minds of the
enlightened youth what they had to the strictly orthodox. A treatment of the
unfortunate souls, such as was portrayed traditionally, seemed to them
monstrous, and subverting man's idea of the goodness of Ohrmazd. They
<span class="t0 t5 t6 t14 t18 hoverable">thought</span> them to be crude and archaic. The germs of <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> <span class="t0 t5 t6 t14 t18 hoverable">thought</span> were
sprouting <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the young, and they viewed these theological problems
with a changed attitude. They gradually became estranged from all beliefs
that had been instilled into them from childhood. They aimed at reconciling
religion and contemporary knowledge, and bringing religious beliefs and
practices into closer relation with the intellectual ways and thought. Parsi
orthodoxy resented it.
An illiterate priesthood failed to satisfy the intellectual wants of the
enlightened youth. The Parsi priesthood had <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> before degenerated into
ignorance. The situation was not keenly felt so <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> as the laity was equally
illiterate. But now when the latter sought enlightenment, the clergy had kept
less and less abreast of the times. During the <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> period of twelve centuries,
very few priests rose above mediocrity. The priest hitherto had acted as an

intercessor between the layman and Ohrmazd, and through elaborate ritual
had undertaken to gain for him <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> help, being duly paid to recite
penitential prayers for the expiation of the sins of the living, and to <span class="t27 hoverable">sacrifice</span>
for the purchase of paradise for the dead. The youth of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> school
argued that there was no more need of the Mobad's mediation between him
[485]and his Heavenly Father. He demanded that the priest should act as a
moral preceptor, a <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> ministrant to his soul. This, in those times, the
priest <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> not do. He <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> not widen his religious outlook and adapt
himself to the demand of the younger generation. The youth now grew up
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> religious instruction and gradually gravitated towards indifferentism.
The apathy, callousness, and disregard towards religion on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the
educated youth waxed stronger <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> by day, and culminated in an
atmosphere of agnosticism that withered the beliefs in which they were
<span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> up. Agnosticism became the threatening <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> of the day.
[486]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LVII
INTRODUCTION OF THE WESTERN METHOD OF IRANIAN
SCHOLARSHIP IN INDIA
Parsi scholarship at this period. Up to that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the Avestan texts had been
almost wholly interpreted by the Zoroastrian authorities through the help of
their Pahlavi translations. The original Avestan texts had remained largely
unintelligible <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> the Pahlavi version. It was not then <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> that the
Gathas were composed in metre, <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> less the fact that some other minor
texts were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> metrical. The rudiments of Avestan grammar that various
inflections modified the <span class="t6 t13 t14 t25 t27 hoverable">meaning</span> of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">word</span> had been a <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> forgotten fact.
This was due to the circumstance that, owing to the inflectional poverty of
the Pahlavi language, the translators had resorted to the use of particles and
very often had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> dropped this only <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> of indicating the syntactical
relation of <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">words</span> in a sentence, and had contented themselves with
rendering an inflected Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">word</span> by its uninflected crude Pahlavi
equivalent. Firdausi and other Moslem writers were the sole informants of
the Parsi scholars regarding the ancient and legendary history of Iran. As
these did not record the doings of the Achaemenian kings, the Parsi

community remained <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any inkling of the greatness and glory of the
illustrious Parsi kings of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Persian empire. European history had now
for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> startled the English-educated Parsi youth with the
information that there once flourished a mighty dynasty of rulers whom the
modern Parsi can claim as his kith and kin. The <span class="t3 t7 t9 t10 t15 t19 t22 hoverable">truth</span> had been denied for
centuries to their legitimate descendants in India and Persia that a Cyrus or a
Darius, a Xerxes or an Artaxerxes, who had carried the Persian banner in war
to the farthest ends of the world, were historically their own coreligionists.
In vain did the august Farohar of Darius hover round the rock of Behistan for
over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> thousand <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">years</span> in pious expectation of some Parsi traveller who
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> trace his steps [487]to this hallowed place, climb the rock to
read the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> king's record, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> it <span class="t6 t10 t15 hoverable">known</span> to the world, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> earn the
royal monarch's blessings whispered in the solemn silence by as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span>
tongues as there were wedges and angles in the letters of the carved
inscriptions. Such, in short, was the deplorable state of Parsi scholarship
when comparative philology <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> to its aid from the West and opened a
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> era of critical study in the field of Iranian researches.
Introduction of the science of comparative philology <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the Parsis.
Since the year 1771, when that worthy pioneer of romantic renown in
Iranian studies, Anquetil du Perron, published his volumes containing the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> European translation of the Avesta, or Sacred <span class="t25 hoverable">Book</span> of Zoroaster, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
strides forward have been <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> in Europe and America in the realm of
Iranian research. The field is now replete with the lasting monuments of
Western scholarship whether in the department of standard editions of the
sacred texts or the compilation of grammars and dictionaries or again in the
preparation of scientific translations as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as in making exegetical,
philological and archeological researches. The service that these scholars
have rendered to the Parsis is greater than can <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> be expressed. To K. R.
Kama, Parsi pioneer of the Iranian studies on Western lines in India, who had
studied the Avestan texts in Europe under the German savant Spiegel, is due
the credit of introducing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> Parsi scholars the science of comparative
philology and the scientific method of interpreting their sacred books. The
inauguration of this <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> era belongs to the early <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the <span class="t6 hoverable">second</span> half of
the last century.

Textual criticism brings startling revelation for the Parsis. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span>
outcome of the critical study of the Avestan literature, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be judged
from intimations <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> above, was the discovery <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> by the Western
scholars that the grammar, style, and internal evidence of the extant Avestan
texts show that they were not composed at a single period and by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span>
person, but that they were the products of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> persons who worked at
various times. Scholars such as these undertook to determine the
approximate dates of the component parts of the Avesta. The Gathas were
shown to be the oldest in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of composition and the authorship of a
considerable portion, if not all, of these [488]hymns was ascribed to
Zoroaster himself.. The prophet's work, it was said, was continued by his
immediate disciples, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">must</span> have extended over a very <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> period after
him, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> the immediate impression <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> by Zoroaster himself <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span>
be acknowledged to have <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> fainter in succeeding generations. The
religion of the Younger Avesta had departed in <span class="t3 hoverable">certain</span> respects from the
religion of the Gathas, and the subsequent compositions showed signs of
degeneration both in substance and style. The simple and abstract <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
the Gathas was blurred if not lost, and the development of the later texts
tended to <span class="t8 t13 hoverable">become</span> more complex and concrete. We breathe a <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span>
atmosphere, they declared, when we <span class="t5 hoverable">pass</span> from the Gathic to the Later
Avestan field. Nature-worship, which Zoroaster strove to supplant by a
higher type of ethical religion, was shown to have been reinstated in these
later texts. The masses <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> not be weaned from the beliefs that loomed
large in their eyes, and thus, the scholars maintained, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> practices
abolished by Zoroaster were later resuscitated by the clergy. Startling indeed
were these <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> ideas that philological re searches <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> to the Parsis, who
had been accustomed to at tribute indiscriminately all Avestan compositions
to Zoroaster himself and who <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> approached their own sacred books with
a historical perspective.
Back to the Gathas was the war-cry of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> school. This critical
estimate of their scripture by the Iranian scholars of the West greatly
influenced the young Parsi scholars in India. They now hailed the Gathas as
providing a self-sufficient religious system in themselves. They claimed to
have discovered the only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> mirror in which the genuine teachings of
Zoroaster were, reflected. The Later Avestan texts were declared to render

nugatory the pristine purity. An exuberant outgrowth of dogmatic theology
and ceremonial observances, they asserted, had supplanted the buoyant
simplicity of the Gathic teachings, and simply' represented a decline from
the pure teachings of Zoroaster. The names of the Amshaspands in the
Gathas were considered to be merely descriptive of the attributes of
Ohrmazd. These attributes, they insisted, had crystallized into concrete
beings, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> converting the monotheistic religion of Zoroaster into a
veritable system of polytheism. Tradition, they argued, attributed to
Zoroaster doctrines that he <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> preached. They advocated a return to the
[489]original purity of the faith by stripping off the accretions that had
gathered round the pure canon of the prophet, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> removing the haze of
ignorance and bigotry that had overclouded the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of their excellent
religion. All this was highly sacrilegious to orthodox ears. Such statements
roused the strong resentment of the community and elicited vehement
protests from priests and laymen alike. The <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> school was assailed on all
sides. More sober opinion intervened to modify the sweeping assertions, and
declared that while the Gathas, of course, should be <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> as the norm, there
should <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> be admitted into the Zoroastrian canon such parts of the later
scriptures as were in accord with the Gathic spirit; but whatever <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> not be
traced to the Gathas was adventitious, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> not deserving of
acceptance. The problem at once arose as to who was going to distinguish
the authoritative from the un-authoritative and a <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> controversy opened
amid still more bitter feelings.
A <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> theory to defend the Gathas from the accusation of dualism. The
salient feature of dualism in the Iranian faith has <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> been the chief point
assailed by the non-Zoroastrians, both in ancient and modern times,
whenever they have entered into religious disputations with the followers of
the prophet. They have laid the doctrine of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> to the charge of
Zoroastrianism. The accidentals of the controversy have varied materially in
their character at <span class="t1 t2 t18 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">different</span> periods, but the main point of contention has <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span>
remained the same. We have already seen how vehemently the learned
prelates of the Pahlavi period strove to vindicate this characteristic feature of
the Zoroastrian teachings. <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">Far</span> from considering it a weak point, they hailed
it the only possible solution of the problem of evil. Not so their modern
descendants. The repeated attack of the Christian missionaries, and the

strong influence of the Western literature, which hailed monotheism as the
<span class="t6 t9 t22 t29 hoverable">highest</span> category of theology, <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> about an unprecedented change in
this belief; and so powerful has this influence been, that we hardly <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> find
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> at this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> any learned Parsi priest or layman marshalling arguments in
vindication of the doctrine. Attempts are now generally <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> either to
explain it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">away</span> by ingenious arguments or to speak of it apologetically. Haug
was the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> to <span class="t22 hoverable">bring</span> it to the notice of the Parsis that [490]the leading idea
of the Gathas was monotheism. Ahura Mazda, he declared, is the supreme
godhead, who has produced the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival principles Spenta Mainyu and
Angra Mainyu as his twin spirits. Separated as they seem, they are united in
action. They are indispensable to each other in the formation and conduct of
the universe. They are the creative and the destroying, constructive and
destructive powers of God, and are as inseparable from each other as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and
night. The opposition rests with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival spirits, and nowhere in the
Gathas does Angra Mainyu, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Spirit, stand in direct opposition to
Ahura Mazda. This fundamental distinction, he said, is lost sight of in the
late period, and we find in the Vendidad that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> Spenta Mainyu
is identified with Ahura Mazda himself, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> Angra Mainyu
stands in direct antagonism to God. The Parsi scholars who were <span class="t29 hoverable">ever</span> in
search for some <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> arguments to remove the so-called weak point of their
faith eagerly embraced this <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">new</span> explanation, which, they thought, saved the
Gathas at least from the stain of dualism. If the Vendidad and other later
<span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> introduced it in the Zoroastrian theology, it was a decided fall, they
claimed, from the original pure monotheism. The prophet himself <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span>
taught dualism, they argued, and it is unfair to ascribe that doctrine to him,
for which the enlightened youth had to blush before modern criticism!
[491]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LVIII
CHRISTIAN MISSIONARIES ATTACK ZOROASTRIANISM
Indifference on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the Parsi youth arouses the proselytizing zeal
of the Christian missionaries. These <span class="t0 t5 t6 t14 t18 hoverable">thought</span> that they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> easily turn the
apathy of the newly educated Parsi youth for his own religion to interest in
the faith of Jesus, if they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> convince him of the superiority of

Christianity over his national creed. The impressionable youth once secured,
they imagined, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> prove a valuable asset in bringing over his enlightened
coreligionists to the Christian fold. Christianity <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> easily spread
downwards <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> the masses, they thought, if only they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> capture the
upper educated classes. The missionaries felt that this handful of the
progressive people, who approached nearest to the Western <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in their
modes of living, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> ultimately be easily won over to their faith. With this
object in view some of them began to study the Zoroastrian scriptures <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span>
hand, during the latter <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> half of the last century. They picked
out what seemed to them to be vulnerable points in the Zoroastrian faith,
and exposed them to the ridicule of the Parsi youth newly tinged with
Western ideas. The community was alarmed at this aggression, the more so
when a couple of converts were actually <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> to Christianity from this class.
Salient features of Zoroastrianism assailed by the missionaries. The
religion of Zoroaster, the controversialists alleged, abounded in absurdities
and incongruities. It was based on the idolatry of nature. The Parsi scholars
repudiated the accusation with indignation, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> that in their reverence
for the elements of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> they <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> worshipped fire, sun, and such other
elements, but venerated the angels presiding over these noble productions of
God, holding them to be his purest symbols.1 1. A Parsi Priest, Tâlim-i
Zurtoosht, p. 15, Bombay, 1840; Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum Râhân (Eng. version),
p. 44, Bombay, 1841. [492]An erroneous rendering of Vd. 19. 9 had led
Anquetil du Perron, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> translator of the Avestan <span class="t2 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t20 t24 t29 hoverable">text</span> into a European
tongue, to depict Boundless <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> principle of the Universe.2 This
interpretation was <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> as an unequivocal testimony of the Zoroastrian
scriptures to corroborate the statement of the Greek and Armenian writers
who had alleged that both Ohrmazd and Ahriman had sprung from Time.
Anquetil's mistake was repeated in the <span class="t9 t16 t26 hoverable">works</span> of the European writers for a
considerable time, until it was finally corrected by the unanimous verdict of
the Iranian scholars of the West during the latter half of the last century.
When the Zoroastrian scriptures were adversely criticized by the
missionaries on the ground that the doctrine of Boundless <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> at the apex
of existence proved the derivative and secondary character of Ormazd,3 the
Parsi priests repudiated the charge and vigorously maintained that the
concept simply designated eternity and <span class="t15 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">nothing</span> more. <span class="t6 t9 t18 t26 hoverable">Far</span> from being

Ormazd's superior, Boundless Time, they affirmed was his creation. 2. ZendAvesta, vol. 1, p. 414; vol. 2, p. 592, Paris 1771.
3. Wilson, The Parsi Religion, p. 134, Bombay, 1843. More heated was the
controversy that hinged <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the alleged belief of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival spirits. We have
already seen 'how dualism has been the main question of inveterate
controversies,; we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> here only advert to it in passing When the missionaries derisively <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the Parsis the worshippers of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> gods, which certainly
they <span class="t0 t10 t11 t14 t18 hoverable">never</span> were, they at once vehemently denied the charge and hastened to
repudiate it by denying downright an objective existence to Ahriman. The
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Spirit, they argued, is not an entity, but merely the symbolic
personification of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> owing his origin to man's errant
thoughts. Outside of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> he has no existence at all. He is a gratuitous
invention. The concept of his existence is purely negative, a chimera. He is
man's creation, as are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> the infernal host of demons and fiends, which are
<span class="t15 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">nothing</span> more than the lusts and passions of man.4
4. A Parsi Priest, Tâlim-i Zurtoosht, p. 62-64, 83, 84; Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum
Râhân (Eng. version); p. 35-37, 73, 74. Parsi apologists meet the charges of
their opponents by resorting to allegorical explanations. This attempt at
giving allegorical interpretations of the scriptures was carried still further.
Tradition had always seen some geographical data in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> [493]chapter
of the Vendidad, and modern scholarship had accepted that view; but in
their polemics with the missionaries the Parsi scholars explained the opening
of the <span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">chapter</span> by asserting that the act of Ohrmazd in creating Iran Vej, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> region of the world, was to be interpreted as a mere figurative expression
for religious faith, and Ahriman's counter <span class="t14 hoverable">creation</span> of winter was emblematic
of infidelity. Similarly, the various places <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> to have been created by
Ohrmazd indicated man's body, and the obnoxious creatures of Ahriman
signified man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> passions.5 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Another</span> instance of the same kind of
interpretation <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be cited. Druj Nasu, or the Demon of Defilement is
spoken of in the Vendidad as taking possession of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who has touched
the corpse of a dog or a man,6 and a minute description is <span class="t1 t2 t4 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> as to how
the demon is successively driven out from the top of the head of the defiled
<span class="t9 hoverable">person</span> to the tips of his toes, as the ablution ceremony is being performed.
This rite was criticized as being revolting to common sense.7 Instead of

defending it on hygienic principles, the learned controversialists again
expatiated <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the mystic significance of the text, and alleged that the
<span class="t3 t5 t7 t9 t20 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> ceremony referred to the internal purification of man, and that Nasu
represented his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> nature, while the successive expulsion of the fiend from
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> to the other, until finally eradicated, meant the gradual
improvement of a man's character.8 Zoroastrianism teaches that the <span class="t26 hoverable">sin</span> of
burying corpses is inexpiable.9 The pulling down of the dakhmas, wherein lie
interred the dead bodies of such men, is a <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t9 t13 t14 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">means</span> of the expiation of one's
sins in thought, word, and deed; and is equivalent to the recital of a Patit.10
Responding to a criticism on this passage, recourse was again <span class="t19 hoverable">taken</span> to
declare it as couched in mysterious language. It was curiously explained to
mean that the dakhma referred to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of man, the corpse stood for his
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> passions, its disinterment meant the expulsion of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> propensities,
and the final exposure to the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the <span class="t0 t8 t11 t14 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">sun</span> signified the enlightenment of
the inner <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> by the <span class="t0 t6 t7 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> wisdom.11
5. A Parsi Priest, Tâlim-i Zurtoosht, p. 35, 36.
6. Vd. 8. 35-71.
7. Wilson, The Parsi Religion, p. 161.
8. Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum Râhân (Eng. version), p. 74; A Parsi Priest Tâtim-i
Zurtoosht, p. 180.
9. Vd. 1. 12; 3. 38, 39.
10. Vd. 7. 51; 13. 57.
11. Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum Râhân, p. 79, 80.
[494] The outcome of this controversy. The Parsis further retaliated by
seizing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the weak points of the Christian scriptures and turning them
into ridicule, just as we have seen, the author of the Shikand Gumanik Vijar
did in the Pahlavi period. Theological questions were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> discussed with
acrimonious zeal on both sides, and a considerable polemic literature was

produced. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">came</span> out of this controversy was that the study of
their own religion began to be prosecuted by the Parsi priests with greater
avidity than before.
[495]
<span class="t12 t19 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LIX
THE REFORM MOVEMENT
Crusade against the non-Zoroastrian practices engrafted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
Zoroastrianism. The compromises and concessions <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">part</span> of the
early Parsi settlers in India were needed to conciliate the prejudices of the
Hindu rulers. The Parsis were a handful of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> living in the midst of the
teeming millions of India, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> the twelve centuries of their residence in
this country have failed to merge them in the ocean of Indian humanity. This
fact is largely due to their intensely communal spirit, fostered by the dread of
being assimilated into greater communities, and of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> losing their
individuality. But the average Parsi did not fail to borrow <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> superstitious
customs and habits from the Hindus as <span class="t1 t2 t4 t6 t8 t10 t12 t13 t14 t17 t19 t23 t25 t28 hoverable">well</span> as from the Mohammedans during the later period. The Hindu augur and the Moslem diviner became
important factors in the family <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the Parsis. These seers were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> in to
cast the horoscope of the new-born Zoroastrian child; they foretold the
future, administered amulets to heal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> sickness and disease in the family,
prescribed charms to ward off the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> eye, exorcised demoniacal influences
from persons possessed by the powers of darkness, and, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">many</span> ways,
proved indispensable auxiliaries to a Parsi from birth to death. The mediation
of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> or of a Mullah was often rated higher than that of a Mobad,,
and a Sanskrit mantra or an Arabic kalma was regarded more efficacious for
the purchase of heavenly boons than an Avestan manthra. The Zoroastrian
priest ruled in the fire-temple, but the non-Zoroastrian priest had a powerful
sway over the hearts of the Parsi populace. With rich offerings did the
faithful repair to the tombs of Moslem saints and to Hindu shrines. They laid
their faith <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> all altars and turned to strange <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> in their extremities. The
grandeur of the Mazdayasnian teachings had faded, and Zoroaster had partly
ceased to be a living force in the <span class="t7 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the community. [496]Many
alien customs had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> worked their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> into Zoroastrianism. These were

hard facts for the orthodox to admit but they were facts all the same. With
the vigour of youth and with unquenchable zeal the reformers of that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span>
undertook to liberate the community from the thraldom of superimposed
non-Zoroastrian customs, and to wean it from superstitions.
The reformers protested against reciting their prayers parrot-wise in an
unintelligible language. The Avesta language had <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> since fallen into
disuse. It was not a living language. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> the belief in its being of celestial
origin, the tongue in which Ohrmazd addressed his heavenly court, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span>
that in which Ahriman harangued his ribald crew, had preserved it as the
only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> vehicle for conveying prayers. The reformers now argued that it
was meaningless to mumble an unintelligible gibberish which <span class="t4 t18 t22 hoverable">neither</span> the
priest himself nor the layman understood. Ejaculations and genuflexions were
of no avail, when they recited their prayers in a dead language. No amount
of such formulas <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> affect the character of the devotees and ennoble their
thoughts. A prayer that had no subjective value was no prayer. It failed to
awaken any ethical fervour, for a truly devout prayer should spur the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t5 t7 t8 t13 t16 t18 t20 t21 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">spirit</span>
<span class="t5 t7 hoverable">within</span> to a higher life. This was not possible so <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> as the priest
perfunctorily droned prayers, not a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">word</span> of which was understood. The
orthodox vehemently retorted that the Avestan language Was divine, and as
such it possessed inherent magical efficacy. Miraculously composed as these
Avestan prayers were, they had indescribable objective value, it was claimed,
quite independent of the motive of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">one</span> who recited them. The mere
utterance of the sacred texts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> knowing in the least what they meant,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> produce marvellous effect. The ultra-orthodox viewed the situation
with pious dread and entertained serious apprehension that, if once the
community permitted the use of Gujarati or English compositions for daily
prayers, <span class="t15 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">nothing</span> short of a revolutionary change <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> come, and with the
lapse of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the Avestan texts <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be supplanted by prayer-books
composed in the modern vernaculars. The reformers pointed out that there
already existed some monajat prayers composed in Persian by some of the
learned Dasturs <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> in their own lifetime, which the orthodox were using
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any scruple at the <span class="t7 t10 t15 t25 hoverable">end</span> of their daily Avestan prayers. [497]A fierce
controversy raged around this question, with the result that the orthodox
<span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> on praying in their own way, and the reformers, <span class="t4 t18 t22 hoverable">neither</span> having faith in
the recital of their prayers in an unintelligible language nor having a proper

substitute to satisfy their demand, <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> prayers of any kind. And the
situation remains, in large measure, unchanged up to this very day.
The Avesta <span class="t2 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t20 t24 t29 hoverable">text</span> metamorphosed into an ungrammatical jargon. The
reformers further <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">said</span> that the Avestan texts were recited with the most
incorrect pronunciations. In vindication of their statement they quoted
passages from the original texts and <span class="t0 t2 t16 t18 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">put</span> by their side the corrupt formulas in
vogue in the community. An example of this kind <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> not be out of <span class="t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span>
here, and we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shall</span> insert the <span class="t2 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t20 t24 t29 hoverable">text</span> of Ahunavar, the most important
Zoroastrian formula, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> in its correct <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> and then in the corrupt <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span>
which obtains <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">among</span> a considerable portion of the community up to this
hour. The original formula is as follows :
yathâ ahu vairyo athâ ratush ashât chit hachâ
vangheush dazdâ manangho shyaothananâm angheush Mazdâi
khshathremchâ ahurâi â yim dregubyo dadat vâstârem.
The corrupt <span class="t6 t7 t8 t9 t13 t14 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of the same:
athâu veryo thâre tose sâde chide châvanghoise dezdâ manengho sotthenanâm anghyos
Mazdâe khosetharamchâe orâe âiyem daregobyo daredar vâstârem.
This, however, did not trouble the orthodox, for they complacently
remarked that as <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> as they had implicit faith in what they recited, and
recited it whole-heartedly, it mattered very little whether they <span class="t27 hoverable">used</span> correct
pronunciation or not. Ohrmazd looked to their hearts, and not to their sense
of grammar and orthography. So <span class="t1 t6 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> as their motives were good, their
prayers were acceptable to the Heavenly Father. The redeeming feature of
this entire controversy has been a growing tendency in the community to
avail itself of the help of the philologist, who has <span class="t2 t4 t5 t22 t23 hoverable">brought</span> nearer home to
them the correct and carefully edited version of their sacred scriptures, and
they have consequently begun to recite their daily prayers from books that
have based their texts on the standard and authorized version of the liturgy.
[498] Too <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> ritualism, protested the reformer. The mechanical
handling of the ritual, which was as <span class="t0 t1 t5 t10 t12 t13 t15 t19 t20 t28 hoverable">much</span> unintelligible in its real purport to
